organization.fullName: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

identificationModule.briefTitle: Transfusion of Pathogen Reduced Cryoprecipitated Fibrinogen to Expedite Product Availability in Perioperative Bleeding
identificationModule.officialTitle: Pilot Clinical Trial of Transfusion of Pathogen Reduced Cryoprecipitated Fibrinogen (INTERCEPT Fibrinogen Complex) in Patients With Bleeding to Expedite Product Availability and Improve Outcomes in Perioperative Bleeding

leadSponsor.name: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

descriptionModule.briefSummary:
The goal of this quality improvement study is to compare pathogen-reduced cryoprecipitate with traditional cryoprecipitate in liver transplant and cardiovascular patients. The investigators hypothesize that by having immediate access to a readily available thawed blood product that replaces fibrinogen (the main substrate of a blood clot), early bleeding can be treated before it escalates into uncontrolled hemorrhage, and therefore additional blood products, like platelets, plasma and red blood cells can be avoided.

Participants will be given one of the two FDA-approved blood products.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Immediately replacing fibrinogen in perioperative bleeding patients with acquired fibrinogen deficiency improves outcomes. The product that is primarily used for fibrinogen replacement in the US, cryoprecipitate (cryo), must be stored frozen and expires six hours after thawing, resulting in a delay in transfusion of approximately 50 minutes from the time it is ordered, as well as unnecessary transfusion of more readily available but not indicated blood components that are transfused while the patients waits for cryo . A modified version of the product, pathogen reduced (PR) cryo, is now FDA approved and can be thawed and stored for 5 days, allowing the product to be available immediately when needed. In this quality improvement study, the investigators will compare the effect that readily available, pre-thawed PR cryo has on transfusion practice in cardiovascular and liver transplant patients who receive PR cryo versus those who receive traditional cryo by randomizing cryo transfusions in the blood bank by month to all cryo or all PR cryo. All clinical decisions, including the need for cryo, and laboratory testing will occur per standard of care.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: The intervention and randomization are not made at the level of the individual patient, but rather on clusters of patients by month. The clusters will include all patients at NYP/WC for whom pooled cryo is ordered during a single month.

armGroups.label: Patients given Traditional Cryo
armGroups.description: These are the liver transplant and cardiothoracic (LT and CT) patients that will be given traditional cryo based on the randomization protocol. The blood bank will alternate use of PR cryo and regular cryo each month for all patients with a cryo order. All patients will receive either traditional cryo or PR cryo in a given month.

armGroups.label: Patients given PR Cryo
armGroups.description: These are the liver transplant and cardiothoracic (LT and CT) patients that will be given PR cryo based on the randomization protocol. The blood bank will alternate use of PR cryo and regular cryo each month for all patients with a cryo order. All patients will receive either traditional cryo or PR cryo in a given month.

interventions.name: Traditional Cryoprecipitate
interventions.description: This is the cryoprecipitate already currently being given to patients with a cryo order.

interventions.name: Pathogen-Reduced Cryoprecipitate
interventions.description: This is the pathogen-reduced cryoprecipitate that is intended to be compared to the standard cryoprecipitate.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Total Number of RBCs Used Over Admission
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within the first 30 days after surgery.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Total Number of Platelets Used Over Admission
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within the first 30 days after surgery.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Total Number of Plasma Used Over Admission
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within the first 30 days after surgery.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of Cryo Units Used Perioperatively
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 3 days post procedure

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of RBCs Used Perioperatively
secondaryOutcomes.description: Number of RBC units transfused during perioperative period
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 3 days post procedure

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of Plasma Used Perioperatively
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 3 days post procedure

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of Platelets Used Perioperatively
secondaryOutcomes.description: Number of platelet units transfused during perioperative period
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 3 days post procedure

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Time From Operating Room (OR) Start Time to Start of Cryo Transfusion
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: procedure (Time from OR start time to start of cryo transfusion)

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Time From Cryo Order to Start of Transfusion
secondaryOutcomes.description: Time to cryo order time to start of cryo transfusion
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: procedure (Time from cryo order to start of transfusion)

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of Cryo Units Wasted by Blood Bank
secondaryOutcomes.description: This captures the Cryoprecipitate units discarded.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Daily, up to approximately 24 months

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Pre Transfusion FIBTEM Amplitude 10 Min After Start of Clot Formation
secondaryOutcomes.description: FIBTEM before transfusion, if anesthesiologist orders it. FIBTEM is a point of care laboratory test measuring fibrinogen contribution to a clot. It is part of ROTEM testing and helps providers determine if patients need fibrinogen supplementation during surgical bleeding.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Variable, but it is generally available within 15 minutes of the start of ROTEM testing.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Post Transfusion FIBTEM Amplitude at 10 Min After Start of Clot Formation
secondaryOutcomes.description: FIBTEM after transfusion, if anesthesiologist orders it. FIBTEM is a point of care laboratory test measuring fibrinogen contribution to a clot. It is part of ROTEM testing and helps providers determine if patients need fibrinogen supplementation during surgical bleeding.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Variable, but it is generally available within 15 minutes of the start of ROTEM testing.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Maximum Clot Firmness (MCF)
secondaryOutcomes.description: The maximum strength of a clot as determined by ROTEM testing.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Variable, but it is generally available within 1 hour of the start of ROTEM testing.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Pre-transfusion Fibrinogen Level
secondaryOutcomes.description: The fibrinogen measurement before cryoprecipitate is transfused.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During surgery, within 3 hours of specimen receipt by laboratory.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Highest Fibrinogen Level Within 24 Hours
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within 24 hours after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Lowest Fibrinogen Level Within 24 Hours
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within 24 hours after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Cumulative Volume in Drains After Surgery (e.g., Chest Tube for CV Surgery) at the Time of Removal
secondaryOutcomes.description: The cumulative volume in drains after surgery (e.g., chest tube for CV surgery) at the time of drain removal
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to approximately 3 days

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Volume in Drains (Chest Tube for CV Surgery)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At 24 hours after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Time From End of Bypass Pump for CV Surgery
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Until end of surgery

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Length of Stay in OR
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Duration of time in operating room

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Length of Stay in ICU
secondaryOutcomes.description: Participant length of stay in ICU setting
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During hospitalization, approximately 5 days to 30 days

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Length of Stay in Hospital
secondaryOutcomes.description: Overall length of stay in hospital
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During hospitalization, approximately 5 days to 30 days

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Need for Ventilator
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During hospitalization, approximately 5 days to 30 days

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Time on Ventilator
secondaryOutcomes.description: If participant was on ventilator, amount of time spent on ventilator
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During hospitalization, approximately 5 days to 30 days

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Overall Cost of Cryo vs PR Cryo, When Factoring Wastage
secondaryOutcomes.description: Cost of traditional cryoprecipitate compared to PR Cryoprecipitate.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Daily, approximately 24 months

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of Participants That Experienced an Adverse Event of Fever
secondaryOutcomes.description: All participants that experience fevers that occur during the time frame
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within 5 days of surgery start time

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of Participants That Experienced an Adverse Event of Infection
secondaryOutcomes.description: All participants that experience infections that occur during the time frame
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within 5 days of surgery start time

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of Participants That Experienced an Adverse Event of Transfusion Reaction.
secondaryOutcomes.description: All participants that experience transfusion reactions that occur during the time frame
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within 5 days of surgery start time

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Fibrinogen Level
secondaryOutcomes.description: Fibrinogen level most proximal to the end of surgery
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Most proximal to end of procedure

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

1. Adult patients undergoing cardiovascular surgery or liver transplant who receive cryo during surgery during the two year study period.
2. Cardiovascular surgery includes the following procedures:

   1. coronary artery bypass grafting
   2. valve repair or replacement
   3. open thoracic aortic and thoracoabdominal aortic surgery
   4. atrial or ventricular septal defects
   5. ventricular assist device implantation or revision
   6. or any combination of the above.

Exclusion Criteria:

1. Patients who do not receive any cryo product in the OR
2. Patients who are not cardiovascular surgery or liver transplant patients
3. Cardiac transplantation surgery
4. Patients who receive a product in error within either the cryo time period or the PR cryo time period. For example, PR cryo during a cryo month or cryo during a PR cryo time month.
5. Patients who receive less than 1 pool (5 units) of cryo
6. Pediatric patients (less than 18 years of age).
7. Patients who received both PR cryo and traditional cryo
8. Pregnant women

groups.title: Patients Given Traditional Cryo
groups.description: These are all liver transplant and cardiothoracic (LT and CT) patients that will be given Traditional Cryo based on the randomization protocol. The blood bank will be randomized by to use either PR Cryo or Traditional Cryo for the entire month for all patients with a Cryo order. The patients included in this arm received Traditional Cryo during a month in which the blood bank was randomized to use Traditional Cryo. The months in which the blood bank was assigned to use Traditional Cryo are as follows: Period 1: Month 1, Period 4: Month 4, Period 5: Month 5, Period 7: Month 7, Period 10: Month 10, and Period 12: Month 12.

groups.title: Patients Given PR Cryo
groups.description: These are all liver transplant and cardiothoracic (LT and CT) patients that will be given PR Cryo based on the randomization protocol. The blood bank will be randomized by to use either PR Cryo or Traditional Cryo for the entire month for all patients with a Cryo order. The patients included in this arm received PR Cryo during a month in which the blood bank was randomized to use PR Cryo. The months in which the blood bank was assigned to use PR Cryo are as follows: Period 2: Month 2, Period 3: Month 3, Period 6: Month 6, Period 8: Month 8, Period 9: Month 9, Period 11: Month 11.

groups.title: Patients Given Traditional Cryo
groups.description:
These are the liver transplant and cardiothoracic (LT and CT) patients that will be given traditional cryo based on the randomization protocol. The blood bank will alternate use of PR cryo and regular cryo each month for all patients with a cryo order. All patients will receive either traditional cryo or PR cryo in a given month.

Traditional Cryoprecipitate: This is the cryoprecipitate already currently being given to patients with a cryo order.

groups.title: Total
groups.description: Total of all reporting groups

measures.title: ASA Score
measures.description: The ASA Score (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status Classification System) assesses a patient's preoperative health. Scores range from 1 to 6. Score 1 indicates healthy; Score 2 indicates mild systemic disease; Score 3 indicates severe systemic disease; Score 4 indicates disease that is a constant threat to life; Score 5 indicates a moribund patient not expected to survive without surgery; Score 6 indicates a brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.

outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Only the cardiac population was included for this analysis. The data was not available for liver transplant patients, so liver transplant patients were excluded from the analysis.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: procedure (Time from OR start time to start of cryo transfusion)

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Cryo Units Wasted by Blood Bank
outcomeMeasures.description: This captures the Cryoprecipitate units discarded.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The blood bank, which is required to follow its standard operating procedures, was not able to document wastage in a way which allowed the investigators to accurately attribute wastage to a specific arm of the study. Therefore, wastage could not be accurately calculated as intended in the study protocol.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Daily, up to approximately 24 months

outcomeMeasures.title: Pre Transfusion FIBTEM Amplitude 10 Min After Start of Clot Formation
outcomeMeasures.description: FIBTEM before transfusion, if anesthesiologist orders it. FIBTEM is a point of care laboratory test measuring fibrinogen contribution to a clot. It is part of ROTEM testing and helps providers determine if patients need fibrinogen supplementation during surgical bleeding.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data for all participants was not available because pre-transfusion FIBTEMs were not clinically ordered for all participants by the treating anesthesiologists. Only participants with pre-transfusion FIBTEMs available were included in this analysis.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Variable, but it is generally available within 15 minutes of the start of ROTEM testing.

outcomeMeasures.title: Post Transfusion FIBTEM Amplitude at 10 Min After Start of Clot Formation
outcomeMeasures.description: FIBTEM after transfusion, if anesthesiologist orders it. FIBTEM is a point of care laboratory test measuring fibrinogen contribution to a clot. It is part of ROTEM testing and helps providers determine if patients need fibrinogen supplementation during surgical bleeding.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data were not available nor collected for this measure because anesthesiologists do not routinely order this for the investigators to have been able to collect it.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Variable, but it is generally available within 15 minutes of the start of ROTEM testing.

outcomeMeasures.title: Maximum Clot Firmness (MCF)
outcomeMeasures.description: The maximum strength of a clot as determined by ROTEM testing.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data for MCF were not collected since clinical decisions are not made based on this value as the measure assumed. As such, there are no data to report. Clinical decisions were made based on A10 (the clot amplitude measured 10 minutes after clot formation start), not the maximum clot firmness (MCF). As A10 was not a pre-specified measure for this protocol, there are no data to report. Data will never be collected for this Outcome Measure.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Variable, but it is generally available within 1 hour of the start of ROTEM testing.

groups.title: Patients Given Traditional Cryo
groups.description:
These are the liver transplant and cardiothoracic (LT and CT) patients that will be given traditional cryo based on the randomization protocol. The blood bank will alternate use of PR cryo and regular cryo each month for all patients with a cryo order. All patients will receive either traditional cryo or PR cryo in a given month.

Traditional Cryoprecipitate: This is the cryoprecipitate already currently being given to patients with a cryo order.

groups.title: Patients Given PR Cryo
groups.description:

Pathogen-Reduced Cryoprecipitate: This is the pathogen-reduced cryoprecipitate that is intended to be compared to the standard cryoprecipitate.

outcomeMeasures.title: Pre-transfusion Fibrinogen Level
outcomeMeasures.description: The fibrinogen measurement before cryoprecipitate is transfused.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Some data were not collected for this measure because anesthesiologists did not routinely order this test.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: During surgery, within 3 hours of specimen receipt by laboratory.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cumulative Volume in Drains After Surgery (e.g., Chest Tube for CV Surgery) at the Time of Removal
outcomeMeasures.description: The cumulative volume in drains after surgery (e.g., chest tube for CV surgery) at the time of drain removal
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: This data were not available for collection in the electronic health record as intended by the investigators, as the data were not clinically documented. Therefore, the cumulative volume in drains after surgery could not be reported as intended in the study protocol.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Up to approximately 3 days

outcomeMeasures.title: Volume in Drains (Chest Tube for CV Surgery)
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Only the cardiac population was included for this analysis. The clinical parameter is not applicable to liver transplant patients, so liver transplant patients were excluded from the analysis.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: At 24 hours after surgery

outcomeMeasures.title: Overall Cost of Cryo vs PR Cryo, When Factoring Wastage
outcomeMeasures.description: Cost of traditional cryoprecipitate compared to PR Cryoprecipitate.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Not available due to unavailable confidential contractual information that would be needed to calculate cost. The contract between the blood suppliers and hospital is confidential, and therefore the investigators were not able to report on cost-related factors as intended in the study protocol. Data will never be collected for this Outcome Measure.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Daily, approximately 24 months

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Serious adverse events: 5 days post-procedure. All cause-mortality: 30 days or discharge from hospital, whichever occurred first.
adverseEventsModule.description: Serious adverse events collected included transfusion reactions. Adverse events collected included fevers and infections. Data were collected using automated scripts with Structured Query Language (SQL) queries of the hospital's centralized data warehouse. Adverse events were assessed weekly by the study team via video conference.
